summary.seg: This is an outstanding example of a manuscript that benefits from an accessible digital version, as its wealth of subject matter makes it of potential interest to a variety of projects. It is a miscellany full of different texts, in which medical writings, poems, theology, fables, proverbs, a French-Latin glossary of names, forms of letter-writing, notes on the properties of plants, and other textual excerpts all sit side-by-side between the covers. Most of the manuscript is written in a clean bookhand, with extensive rubrication and some decoration, meaning that this is not simply an informal commonplace book. Rather, its contents were planned out, and the book itself was produced at some cost. Blank pages allowed for the addition of new material by later hands.

I became aware of this manuscript when I was working on the wide but poorly documented textual tradition of a lapidary I have since termed the Techel/Azareus Complex. The background to this text dates back to Greco-Roman Antiquity, when gemstones were engraved with various mythological motifs. These stones turned up occasionally during the Middle Ages - many still survive in museums and other collections today - but the subjects and iconography had grown unfamiliar (for some examples, see G. Max Bernheimer's guide). The lapidary in question begins in some versions (including the present manuscript, f. 204v) with the assertion that this book describes the properties of the sigils that the Israelites made while wandering in the desert. However, the descriptions that follow are recognizably the Greco-Roman figures we find on Classical cameos and intaglios. The discovery of such stones appears to have prompted speculation about the magical properties they might possess.

The lapidary is instantly recognizable by entries that begin with the phrase 'Si inveneris...' ('If you find...'), followed by a description of the iconography, precision about the kind of stone it is engraved on, and a list of the wondrous effects it can produce. But no two copies of this lapidary are quite the same. As the text was transmitted, the arrangement of its contents shifted, and material was both added and omitted. This is not uncommon in texts like lapidaries, herbals, and recipe collections. However, this text had a particularly remarkable tendency to incorporate other lapidaries into it, thereby creating an ever-widening network of related material. The version in this manuscript at Cambridge University Library is no exception. On f. 206r, the text switches to a treatment of the general properties of unengraved stones, which surely originated separately, before continuing with descriptions of the engraved ones on f. 206v.

The presence of this text in the collection does not necessarily mean that the compiler possessed any such stones, although of course it is possible. Other texts in the volume reveal an interest in the special properties of stones and plants, many of which concern their ability to heal various ailments. In this respect, the Techel/Azareus Complex is no different. We cannot say whether the compiler's concern was more practical or theoretical, but the later addition of medical recipes on blank pages does suggest that the owner(s) of this book had a continuing interest in cures and remedies.

While I was carrying out my research on the Techel/Azareus Complex, there were simply too many references to lapidaries in manuscript catalogues, usually containing nothing but the generic title 'De lapidibus' ('On stones'). I couldn't view them all. I had to prioritize the manuscripts I had a reasonable belief would contain the right text, whether through more details in the catalogue description or by the presence of certain other texts that sometimes accompanied it. In this case, I had a reasonable certainty of what I would find in Cambridge, because John M. Riddle was gracious enough to send me his handwritten notes on this text, where he listed this present manuscript. Even so, I probably could not have justified the trip if I had not had a list of several Cambridge manuscripts I also needed to see for this and other projects. If I were starting on that same project today, it would be an entirely different experience thanks to the progress in digitizing manuscripts.

Dr Katelyn Mesler
Bibelglossare als verborgene Kulturträger
Heidelberger Akademie der Wissenschaften

msItem.title: Florilegium
msItem.incipit: 1r Confortare in domino
msItem.explicit: 188v erimus quandoque quod hic est.
msItem.note: Early modern hand added title 'Sententiae, sive Flores, ex Sanctis Patribus, praesertim Sancto Augustino et Bernardo, Isidoro' (f. ii recto)
Occasional verses of various length: f. 8r 'Stella maris metricis catharis merito veneraris'.
Includes several subdivisons that have been indicated either with rubrics or large initials, or both.

msItem.title: Theological miscellany
msItem.rubric: 8r Documentum bone fortune qualiter possumus illuminari
msItem.incipit: 8r Ecce descripsi cani tibi
msItem.explicit: 30v est fons uitae. Amen.
msItem.note: Theological miscellany, mostly written in schematic form.

msItem.title: Documentum bone fortune
msItem.author: Bonaventura (?)
msItem.rubric: 30v Documentum bone fortune qualiter homo possit Deo placuere et amplius proficere de bono in melius
msItem.incipit: 30v Primo studeat quam potest uilissimum
msItem.explicit: 36r quibus magis es obligatus.
msItem.note: On this work, see G. E. Mohan O.F.M., 'Initia Operum Franciscalium (XIII-XV S.): I-Q', Franciscan Studies, 37 (1977), 177*-375* (p. 299*)..

msItem.title: Theological extracts
msItem.incipit: 36v De malo alterius es tuum non inquies
msItem.explicit: 39v nisi luctus et anxietas.

msItem.title: Theological extracts
Theological extracts
msItem.rubric: 39v Abiectio ambrosius de offic. libro prime In epistola ccxlvij
msItem.incipit: 40r Abiectio dissipuli detrimentum est magistri
msItem.explicit: 176r Zelum tuum inflammet caritas, informet scientia, firmet constantia, sit fervidus, sit circumspectus, sit invictus. Nec temporem habeat nec careat discretione nec timidus sit.
msItem.note: A series of moral extracts arranged alphabetically.

msItem.title: Verse on avoiding rheumatism
msItem.incipit:
176r Tu ieiunabis non cenabis vigilabis
Sepe laborabis modius potum sociabis
Istis quinque dabis operam sic reuma fugabis.
msItem.note: Added by a contemporary hand.

msItem.title: Theological extracts
msItem.incipit: 176v Ypocrite humiles uolunt esse sine despectu
msItem.note: Two other extracts added with the main hand.

msItem.title: Theological extracts
msItem.rubric: 177r Quidam flores de libris sancti Augustini
msItem.incipit: 177r Da mihi domine scire
msItem.note: Extracts from Gregory the Great Gregory I, Pope, approximately 540-604, Seneca Seneca, Lucius Annaeus, approximately 4 B.C.-65 A.D., Ambrose Ambrose, Saint, Bishop of Milan, -397, Bernard of Clairvaux Bernard, of Clairvaux, Saint, 1090 or 1091-1153 and Isidore of SevilleIsidore, of Seville, Saint, -636.

msItem.title: Lapidarius metrificatus
msItem.author: Marbod of Rennes
msItem.incipit:
189r Euaus rex arabum legitur scripsisse Neroni
Qui post augustum regnauit in urbe secundus
msItem.explicit:
204v Calculus unicoloris lapis ex re si uocatus
Intuitu solo facit ut sis uictor in hostes.

msItem.title: De lapidibus
msItem.author: Thetel
msItem.incipit: 204v In nomine domini hic est preciosus liber magnus de sigillis lapidum et de uirtutibus eorum quodque fecerunt filii isrl in deserto post exitum de egipto secundum planetarum motus et cursus siderum et quia muulti ad similitdudinem huius falso facti sunt in hoc libello subnotamus. Si inueneris sigillum in lapidem scultum scilicet uirum sedentem super aratum longibarbatum
msItem.explicit: 207v hoc sigillum fertur habuisse gallienus.
msItem.note: Complete text; although A Catalogue of the Manuscripts Preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, II (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1857), p. 546 suggests that the text ends abruptly due to missing leaves. For an edition from another manuscript, see Joan Evans, Magical Jewels (1922), pp. 235-238.

msItem.title: List of French Christian names with their Latin equivalents
msItem.incipit: 208r Constans constancius
msItem.explicit: 208r Marguerite margareta

msItem.title: Facetus
msItem.incipit:
208v Cum nichil utilius humane credo saluti
Quam morum uidisse modos et moribus uti
msItem.explicit:
213r In quacumque domum perrexeris ante screato
Quam subeas tussique loquens et ad hostia stato
msItem.note: The poem is missing words of 8 lines on due to damage to f. 210.

msItem.title: Untitled poem against women
msItem.incipit:
213v Arbore sub quadam dictauit clericus Adam
Quo modo primus Adam peccauit in arbore quadam
msItem.explicit:
214r femina sola vale que nomen habes speciale
femina stella maris sic uirgo maria uocaris

msItem.title: Untitled prose text
msItem.incipit: 214v Secundus fuit philosofus. Hic philosofatus est omni tempore silencium observans pictagoricam ducens uitam
msItem.explicit: 217v legisset et causam didicisset quare secundus in silencio philosofaretur precepit eius libros sacros bibliothece inseri et titulari. secundi philosofi.

msItem.title: Exordia [Forms of letter-writing]
msItem.author: Guido Faba
msItem.incipit: 218r Viro prudenti et honesto
msItem.explicit: 223v Premissa igitur graciam actione deuotissima quod me litteris litterisque talibus nostre dulcissime dilectionis dignatio dignata est uisitare. vobis notifico etcaetera

msItem.title: Poem on the Holy Name of Jesus [Dulcis iesu memoria]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Benard of Clairvaux
msItem.incipit: 225r Dulcis ihesu memoria. dans cordi uera gaudia
msItem.explicit: 225r Tunc amplexus tunc oscula que uincunt mellis pocula tunc felix Christi copula nec finiet per secula Amen
msItem.note: Added by a 15th-century hand; another copy of the text is edited in André Wilmart, 'Le "Jubilus" sur le nom de Jésus dit de Saint Bernard', Storia e Letteratura, 2 (Rome, 1944), 146-155 [without this manuscript].

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 225v De abrotano abstinthio vrtica cordeon
msItem.explicit: 225v ysopo dragansia elebero germandrea
msItem.note: The recipe has been added in the 15th century. Another contemporary hand has added: porrum calamentum.

msItem.title: List of (?) divine names or angels
msItem.incipit: 226r Gelian canchel seriel oriel
msItem.note: The names are repeated three times in the same order; added in the second half of the 15th or first half of the 16th century.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit:
227v Scienti bonum et non facienti peccatum est illi
Recogita Christum crucifixum et contra omnia inuenies
msItem.note: Copied by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Flores auctorum
msItem.incipit: 228r Si uis esse aliqui probitas laudatur et alget digito compesce labellum
msItem.explicit:
237v Nobilitas sola est animum quae moribus ornat
Fortis animi est contempriere mortem
msItem.note: Excerpted from Juvenal Juvénal, HoraceHorace, OvidOvid, 43 B.C.-17 A.D. or 18 A.D., the Disticha Catonis, and the Alexandreis of Walter of ChâtillonWalter, of Châtillon, active 1170-1180.

msItem.title: Florilegium from Aesop's Fables
msItem.incipit:
238r Ut iuuet ut prosit conatur pagina presens - incipit
Dulcius arrident seria picta iocis - ysopat
msItem.explicit:
239v Nemo sibi satis est eget omnis amicus amico
Si non uis aliis parcere parce tibi
msItem.finalRubric:
239v Sors aspera monstrat amicum
Explicit ysopat

msItem.title: Tractatus de brevibus et longis
msItem.rubric: 239v Incipit tracatus de breuibus et longis
msItem.note: Only the rubric remains due to the loss of the next folios; the text has not been identified, but another item with the same title occurs in M.XV of the catalogue of the Premonstratensian abbey of Titchfield [see Hampshire Records of Titchfield Abbey. Catalogue of the Library. De situ et forma librarie Monasterii de Tychefeld, ed. by G. W. W. Minns (1892), p. 49..

msItem.title: Decreta metrificata
msItem.incipit:
240r Si quis in hoc opere facto per metra studere
appetit in genere decreta potest retinere
msItem.explicit:
245v Versus decreti summatim iure repleti
Cum sit canon ibi debent in pectore scribi

msItem.title: De viribus herbarum
msItem.author: Floridus Macer [pseudonym of Odo of Meung]
msItem.incipit: 245v De artemisia: Herbarum quasdam dicturus carmine vires
msItem.explicit: 284v Una diagridij si capta solucio fiet

msItem.title: Chapter list for De viribus herbarum
msItem.incipit: 285r De arthemisia .1.
msItem.explicit: 285r De aloe - 40
msItem.note: The chapter numbers have been added by a later hand that has also added two entries which have faded ('De nigellae 36 - De [...]gal - 38).

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 285v ad potegram altea vrtica
msItem.explicit: 286r portulaca origanum dauci spigenardi absinthum
msItem.note: Written over erased text, and followed by a partially erased ingredients in the same 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Largely erased, but with a few French words remaining on f. 286r: 'epilance' (epilepsy); written by the same 15th-century hand that added the previous item.

msItem.title: Maxim
msItem.incipit: 287v Cito fama crescit sed non cito fama quiescit
msItem.note: Copied by a late 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Tract on faith healing
msItem.incipit: 287v Dominus noster ihesus Christus dei et virginis filius salus eterna cordencium qui discipulis suis [?micteli] at in vniversum mondum [sic: mundum] ad predicandum euangelium omni creature potestatem dedit ut langores curarent per invocatione sui sanctissimi nominis et per imposicionem manum
msItem.explicit: 288r dedet plenam sanitatem mentis et corporis In nomine patris etcaetera
msItem.note: Copied by a late 15th-century hand, followed by an erased recipe for lepra.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 288v Pro auditu [...] jus . rute beonice
msItem.explicit: 288v isti sanant cancrum
msItem.note: Copied by different late 15th-century hands.

note.p: Paper stubs before f. ii recto and after f. v verso indicate that two later endleaves have been removed: f. [i] and f. [vi].

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
Foliation in arabic numerals in the upper left-hand corner of the versos, corresponding to modern ff. 254v-284v.

list.item: Quire 1812-2 (ff. 201-210: 8th and 9th leaves missing, after f. 207)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the lower margins of last versos, sometimes in brown frames with minor decoration

supportDesc.condition: Part of the lower half of f. 210 was cut out and later repaired with blank parchment; cuts in the outer margin of f. 81 and the lower margin of f. 125 have been repaired with paper; large vertical cuts in f. 289 and f. 226 and a horizontal cut in f. 234 are sewn with white thread.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 23-28 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The manuscript's main script is Northern Gothica Textualis.
The added text on ff. 223v-225r has been written in a later Northern Gothica Textualis.
Additional recipes and sayings on ff. 225r-227v, 285v-289v are written in different 15th-century cursive hands, including both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Large red initials with brown penwork decoration inside the letter and pen-flourishing, mostly four- to five-lines, but opening with a six-line initial on f. 1r with partial (three-sided) border of pen-flourshing in brown ink with red accents; one initial on f. 61r features pen-flourishing with a bearded man's head; and one on f. 110r a flower.
One five-line black initial in a frame of red ink and with red pen-flourshing on f. 84r.
Small one- or two-line initials in red, some with some pen flourishing in brown ink.
Abstract and antropomorphic letters 'N' at the beginning of lines on ff. 9r, 46v, 58v, 117r.
Diagram lines and line-fillers in red.
Human faces with red accents attached to capitals on or above the upper line on ff. 46v, 71r, 74v, and 117r, some with knotwork decoration.
Headers rubricated in red ink throughout.
A frame for a catchwords decorated in the shape of a (?) fish on ff. 104v, 129v.
Run-over symbols include fleurs-de-lis in brown ink that have been highlighted in red, e.g. f. 146r.

additions.p: A table of contents in a 17th-century hand on f. ii recto.
Marginal annotations to the manuscript in 15th-century script throughout ff. 1r-188v.

note.p: A collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink, c. 1958 ([b] recto).

binding.p: Eighteenth-century paneled brown calf consisting of an outer frame of double and a central frame of triple blind-stamped lines with corner fleurons.
Binding height: 125 mm, width: 80 mm, depth: 55 mm.
Paper pastedowns on the inside covers contain printed text from a poem drawing from Classical sources, including Virgil's Aeneid (see also MS Ff.6.51).
Paper shelf mark labels and gold-tooled spine label of red Russia leather (goldstamped with the title: 'Tracts M.S.') from a previous binding have been pasted onto the inside upper cover.

Rebacked. Three raised bands on the spine. Spine compartments separated with horizontal blind-tooled fillets on top of the raised band. The title "Florilegium" tooled in gold and in a rectangular label affixed to the spine the class-mark "Ff.6.53" tooled in gold. White head and tail bands.
A note on f. [a] recto states that the manuscript was repaired by Douglas Cockerell and Son at Grantchester in August 1970.

history.provenance: One of the manuscripts of Richard Holdsworth (1590-1649), Master of Emmanuel College Holdsworth, Richard, 1590-1649.
history.acquisition: Acquired by the University Library in July 1664: no. 180 in the inventory of Holdsworth's manuscripts compiled by William Crowe (MS Ff.4.27 / Dd.8.45).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.custEvent: Recorded as no. 447 in an inventory of Cambridge University Library's manuscripts compiled c. 1672 (now Cambridge, University Library, MS Oo.7.59).

monogr.title: Die Handschriftliche Überlieferung der Werke des Heiligen Augustinus

series.title: Sitzungsberichte (Österreichische Akademie der Wissenschaften. Philosophisch-Historische Klasse). Veröffentlichungen der Kommission zur Herausgabe des Corpus der Lateinischen Kirchenväter, Heft 3,4

monogr.title: Medieval and Renaissance Letter Treatises and Form Letters: A Census of Manuscripts Found in Part of Western Europe, Japan, and the United States of America

analytic.title: The Medieval Lapidary of Techel/Azareus on Engraved Stones and Its Jewish Appropriations

revisionDesc.change: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library; Tuija Ainonen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
